prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Resolving [CII] from PKS0215+015
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
[CII] 158 um from PKS0215+015 Here we plan to image the [CII] line at 0.2" resolution. If the line is extended, then it clearly arises from star formation activity. By comparing the line strength with the underlying continuum we can then map the FUV strength across the system at 1.7 kpc resolution.
We have previously detected the [CIi] line with our spectrometer ZEUS on the CSO and base our time estimates and S/N ratios on the observed line flux of 5.1E-18 W/m^2.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We want maximum bandwidth to enable detection of the continuum and the very broad (500 km/sec) line widths that we expect.

We wish to resolve the source at the level that we can distinguish between the large scale [CII] emission region predicted by our PDR modeling, and the small scale of [CII] emission that migh occure if the line arose from within AGN features such as the NLR or XDRs in the torus. 2" (16 kpc) is significantly larger than the expected source size in the PDR scenario, and 0.2" (which corresponds to 160 pc) is sufficiently small to isolate the [CII] line emission to the nucleus, if the AGN is the source of excitement.

The total [CII] line flux is 9.4E-18 W/m^2, or 402 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 1.34 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 54 mJy. Per 50 km/s bin we achieve S/N = 10.8, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 26. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 132.
We want maximum bandwidth to enable detection of the continuum and the very broad (500 km/sec) line widths that we expect.

We wish to resolve the source at the level that we can distinguish between the large scale [CII] emission region predicted by our PDR modeling, and the small scale of [CII] emission that migh occure if the line arose from within AGN features such as the NLR or XDRs in the torus. 2" (16 kpc) is significantly larger than the expected source size in the PDR scenario, and 0.2" (which corresponds to 160 pc) is sufficiently small to isolate the [CII] line emission to the nucleus, if the AGN is the source of excitement.

The total [CII] line flux is 3.8E-18 W/m^2, or 168 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 0.56 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 22 mJy. Per 50 km/s bi we achieve S/N = 3.1, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 7.6. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 38.
We want maximum bandwidth to enable detection of the continuum and the very broad (500 km/sec) line widths that we expect.

We wish to resolve the source at the level that we can distinguish between the large scale [CII] emission region predicted by our PDR modeling, and the small scale of [CII] emission that migh occure if the line arose from within AGN features such as the NLR or XDRs in the torus. 2" (16 kpc) is significantly larger than the expected source size in the PDR scenario, and 0.2" (which corresponds to 160 pc) is sufficiently small to isolate the [CII] line emission to the nucleus, if the AGN is the source of excitement.

The total [CII] line flux is 6.4E-18 W/m^2, or 282 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 0.94 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 38 mJy. Per 50 km/s bin we achieve S/N = 9.5, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 22. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 116.
We want maximum bandwidth to enable detection of the continuum and the very broad (500 km/sec) line widths that we expect.

We wish to resolve the source at the level that we can distinguish between the large scale [CII] emission region predicted by our PDR modeling, and the small scale of [CII] emission that migh occure if the line arose from within AGN features such as the NLR or XDRs in the torus. 2" (16 kpc) is significantly larger than the expected source size in the PDR scenario, and 0.2" (which corresponds to 160 pc) is sufficiently small to isolate the [CII] line emission to the nucleus, if the AGN is the source of excitement.

The total [CII] line flux is 2.0E-17 W/m^2, or 723 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 2.42 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 96 mJy. Per 50 km/s bin we achieve S/N = 6.9, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 17. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 85.
We want maximum bandwidth to enable detection of the continuum and the very broad (500 km/sec) line widths that we expect.

We wish to resolve the source at the level that we can distinguish between the large scale [CII] emission region predicted by our PDR modeling, and the small scale of [CII] emission that migh occure if the line arose from within AGN features such as the NLR or XDRs in the torus. 2" (16 kpc) is significantly larger than the expected source size in the PDR scenario, and 0.2" (which corresponds to 160 pc) is sufficiently small to isolate the [CII] line emission to the nucleus, if the AGN is the source of excitement.

The total [CII] line flux is 4.2E-17 W/m^2, or 1585 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 5.28 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 211 mJy. Per 50 km/s bin we achieve S/N = 15, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 37. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 184.
We want maximum bandwidth to enable detection of the continuum and the very broad (500 km/sec) line widths that we expect.

The total [CII] line flux is 9.3E-18 W/m^2, or 315 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 1.05 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 42 mJy. Per 50 km/s bin we achieve S/N = 5.0, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 12. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 61.

The total [CII] line flux is 1.74E-18 W/m^2, or 77 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 0.26 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 10 mJy. Per 50 km/s bin we achieve S/N = 3.3, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 8. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 40.
We want maximum bandwidth to enable detection of the continuum and the very broad (500 km/sec) line widths that we expect.

We wish to resolve the source at the level that we can distinguish between the large scale [CII] emission region predicted by our PDR modeling, and the small scale of [CII] emission that migh occure if the line arose from within AGN features such as the NLR or XDRs in the torus. 2" (16 kpc) is significantly larger than the expected source size in the PDR scenario, and 0.2" (which corresponds to 160 pc) is sufficiently small to isolate the [CII] line emission to the nucleus, if the AGN is the source of excitement.

The total [CII] line flux is 1.41E-17 W/m^2, or 489 Jy-km/s. Over the 300 km/s line width, this corresponds to an average flux density of 1.63 Jy. Assuming the source size is 1", then the average flux density per 0.2" beam is 65 mJy. Per 50 km/s bin we achieve S/N = 3.8, so that integrated over the line the S/N is 9.3. Integrating over the 25 beams that cover the source, the total S/N becomes 47.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to image the [CII] line emission and underlying continuum in a selection of 8 redshift 1-2 galaxies that we previously detected in [CII] with our ZEUS spectrometers. We have used the [CII]/FIR continuum ratio to measure the FUV field strength, hence spatial extent of star formation in 24 z~1-2 galaxies. Our measurements indicate moderate intensity star formation extended to >5 kpc scales for SF dominated systems. This is likely the result of Schmidt-Kennicutt law star formation in thick molecular "disks". This "quiescent" mode of starformation may be dominant for highest L(FIR) galaxies in this epoch, in sharp contrast to the intense major merger induced starbursts found in local ULIRG galaxies. We propose to test our conclusions by resolving the starformation activity in [CII] with ALMA. We also hope to probe the fraction of the [CII] emission that arises from AGN-NLR/XDRs with the high resolution imaging. This is a resubmission of program that was approved (top 10%) Cycles 0 and 1 and Cycle 1 rolled over into Cycle 2, but still not carried out. The program is based on following up ZEUS-1/2 detections of the [CII] line from redshift 1 and 2 systems
